sets.description: Prankster Spidops is the optimal Sticky Web setter for hyper offense teams. Spikes and Toxic Spikes add more residual damage for opposing switch-ins, which can be valuable for securing KOs. Taunt is used to block setup and Defog, while Circle Throw forces switches and can rack up residual damage in combination with Spikes. Focus Sash is used to ensure that Spidops can get up Sticky Web and at least one layer of Spikes before fainting. Slow wallbreakers like Chi-Yu and Quaquaval appreciate the opportunities provided by Sticky Web support. Setup attackers such as Chien-Pao and Ceruledge also pair well with Spidops, as it enables them to outspeed would-be revenge killers. Spidops struggles to set Sticky Web against spinners, so it's recommended to pair Spidops with a Ghost-type like Earth Eater Skeledirge that can beat spinners like Iron Treads. Additionally, common Dark-types like Kingambit and Roaring Moon can set up on Spidops lacking Circle Throw, so pairing it with a strong Fighting type like Slither Wing is advised.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Pawmot leverages its potent typing that hits popular defensive staples such as Corviknight and Ting-Lu to serve as a powerful wallbreaker. Expert Belt capitalizes on Pawmot's great coverage, while Choice Band allows 2HKOs on neutral targets like Scream Tail and Skeledirge; alternatively, Magic Guard + Life Orb with Double Shock and Thunder Punch can also be used for similar neutral damage and the freedom to switch moves. Mach Punch allows Pawmot to beat faster offensive mons such as Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Greninja. Ice Punch allows Pawmot to reliably OHKO Garchomp and beat Clodsire, while Volt Switch can keep up momentum against defensive switch-ins such as Scream Tail and Fluffy Brambleghast. Jolly lets Pawmot outspeed Garchomp and non-Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks, while an Adamant nature bolsters its 2HKO chances on targets such as Scream Tail and Skeledirge with Choice Band Wild Charge. Pawmot often struggles to switch in safely, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Iron Treads that can safely pivot Pawmot in.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Garganacl finds itself as a Stealth Rock setter that fits on balance and stall teams with its ability to force progress through passive damage and maintain entry hazards by annoying popular hazard removal options with Salt Cure. Toxic Debris allows Garganacl to punish weak physical attacks like U-turn from Corviknight and Meloetta, while Earth Eater allows it to check and set up with Iron Defense or Curse on Ground-types like Iron Treads, Landorus-T, and Garchomp, and Water Absorb allows it to check Greninja, Inteleon, and Quaquaval lacking Close Combat. Stealth Rock pairs well with Salt Cure, as Salt Cure heavily chips common hazard removal options like Iron Treads and Corviknight, while Iron Defense and Curse allow Garganacl to act as a bulky cleaner late-game. Protect allows Garganacl to scout the opponent's move, heal with Leftovers, and force more passive damage on foes, while Earthquake and Body Press hit Magic Guard Pokemon like Quaquaval and Heatran that otherwise switch in freely. Garganacl's inability to check common special wallbreakers like Sheer Force Iron Moth and Enamorus-T makes pivots like Regieleki and Slither Wing and physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao great partners; in return, they appreciate Garganacl's ability to maintain Stealth Rock on the field and annoy their checks like Hisuian Goodra and Corviknight with Salt Cure. Garganacl gets rapidly worn down by entry hazards when carrying Leftovers, making physically defensive hazard removal options like Corviknight and defensive Quaquaval good partners; these Pokemon also check physical wallbreakers that threaten Garganacl like Galarian Zapdos, while it checks the special wallbreakers that threaten them. The aforementioned Magic Guard Quaquaval checks Garganacl lacking Iron Defense + Body Press and can spin away Garganacl's Stealth Rock; Desolate Land Skeledirge can spinblock Quaquaval effectively, making it a good partner for Garganacl.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Armarouge is a passable revenge killer that outspeeds naturally fast Pokemon like Cinderace and Chien-Pao, threatening them with its high-Base Power STAB attacks. Moreover, it can clean up late-game easily thanks to Psychic Surge, which protects it from common priority attacks such as Slither Wing's First Impression and Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Trick cripples bulky foes it can't immediately threaten like Blissey, Florges, and Garganacl. Focus Blast hits Chi-Yu and Roaring Moon, while Psyshock 2HKOes Clodsire. Utility moves in Destiny Bond and Will-O-Wisp can also be used, with the former checking setup sweepers like Talonflame and the latter punishing switch-ins. Wallbreakers like Greninja can overwhelm shared checks and appreciate Armarouge's Psychic Terrain protecting them from the likes of Ceruledge's Shadow Sneak. Armarouge's susceptibility to entry hazards makes teammates like Defog Corviknight and Rapid Spin Iron Treads valuable options.

sets.name: Sword of Ruin
sets.description: Sword of Ruin Ceruledge is a potent wallbreaker, thanks to its excellent coverage hitting almost everything in the tier for neutral damage, a high Attack stat, and Bitter Blade offsetting Life Orb recoil. Shadow Sneak picks off faster foes like Gengar and weakened Iron Moth, Hisuian Electrode, and Barraskewda, while Swords Dance can be used to boost Ceruledge's already high damage, letting it OHKO defensive Kommo-o, physically defensive Garchomp, and Zapdos. Close Combat OHKOes Roaring Moon, Well-Baked Body Kingambit, and Garganacl. Fast Pokemon such as Sandy Shocks, Walking Wake, and Chien-Pao force Ceruledge out, so it pairs excellently with bulky Pokemon that can wall them like RegenVest Roaring Moon, Empoleon, and Quaquaval, respectively; in return, Ceruledge can threaten their checks such as Scream Tail and Heatran. Ceruledge can quicky be worn down by Life Orb and entry hazard chip damage, so it appreciates hazard removal from the likes of Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Mandibuzz. Due to Ceruledge's frail defenses and several weaknesses, it often struggles to switch in, so pivots like Corviknight, Zapdos, and Manaphy pair excellently with it, being able to pivot it in on Pokemon it threatens.

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Choice Specs Primordial Sea Kilowattrel is an explosive special attacker that takes advantage of Hurricane's and Thunder's accuracy buff in rain to rain down terror on unprepared while also checking Desolate Land users like Iron Moth and Cinderace. Weather Ball is Kilowattrel's best option against Ground-types like Iron Treads and Landorus-T which shrug off its other offensive options while also chipping Desolate Land Heatran and Cinderace. Pivoting partners like Landorus-T and Corviknight pair with Killowattrel to create a potent VoltTurn core, constantly creating momentum to easily bring each other in and deal big damage. Because of its ability to force switches, Kilowattrel appreciates teammates like Garchomp and Scream Tail that can both set entry hazards and mitigate its own frailty by switching in. Additionally, because of its weakness to Stealth Rock and inability to heal itself, hazard removers like Corviknight and Iron Treads are required to prolong its life and maximize the amount of times it can switch in. Finally, RegenVest users like Hisuian Goodra and Meloetta both comfortably shrug off Kilowattrel's attacks, so physically offensive teammates like Slither Wing and Chien-Pao can chip or remove them, escalating Kilowattrel's potency as a sweeper.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Brambleghast boasts several attributes that make it a ideal choice on hazard stacking teams; its typing is ideal for spinblocking in the face of Donphan, Iron Treads, and Quaquaval, and it offers role compression in Spikes and Rapid Spin. Giga Drain allows Brambleghast to force out Dondozo as well as the aforementioned Rapid Spin users, and Fluffy further enhances its ability to beat such threats. Alternatively, Triage lets it pick off weakened sweepers like Greninja and Sandy Shocks, as well safely use Strength Sap against faster foes. Brambleghast appreciates partners such as Kilowattrel and Sandy Shocks, who threaten Corviknight and dissuade it from using Defog, letting Brambleghast's team maintain entry hazards in the face of both Rapid Spin and Defog. Poison-types like Iron Moth removing Toxic Spikes let Brambleghast not have to worry about switching into Knock Off and getting its Heavy-Duty Boots removed.

sets.name: Tinted Lens
sets.description: Tinted Lens Tinkaton is a solid physical wallbreaker that provides utility while using Tinted Lens to bypass resistances to Gigaton Hammer, turning the tables on defensive Quaquaval and Corviknight, activating teammates like Choice Band Chien-Pao that are hindered by these Pokemon. Metal Coat can be considered as it grants Tinkaton a boosting option for Gigaton Hammer without recoil, granting good odds of OHKOing frailer offensive Pokemon like Ceruledge and Magic Guard Quaquaval after minor chip. Swords Dance allows Tinkaton to more effectively wallbreak, Knock Off is excellent utility that cripples switch-ins like Magic Guard Heatran and Volcanion while annoying switch-ins like Corviknight and Iron Treads, Stealth Rock allows it to act as an offensive entry hazard setter, Protect allows it to gain more Leftovers recovery on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn, and Thunder Wave cripples setup sweepers that may try to capitalize on Gigaton Hammer's cooldown turn. Tinkaton appreciates slow pivots like Corviknight and Meloetta that can live a hit and pivot in Tinkaton safely. Tinkaton also appreciates faster teammates that make up for its lackluster Speed like Roaring Moon and Hisuian Electrode. Entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu pair well with Tinkaton, as it forces numerous switches and removes Heavy-Duty Boots.

sets.name: Palafin
sets.description: Palafin's powerful priority offense and pivoting make it a dangerous threat even with its standard ability. Jet Punch from Palafin-H easily revenge kills dangerous threats like Kilowattrel, Sandy Shocks, and Talonflame, as well as Chien-Pao after minor chip damage. Palafin is heavily hampered by Desolate Land; to take down their users, Zen Headbutt from Palafin-H easily OHKOes Iron Moth and 2HKOes Ceruledge, while Close Combat flings Cinderace into the sun. Pivoting teammates such as Kilowattrel, Meowscarada, and Corviknight not only form dangerous pivoting cores with Palafin, but also position it to both activate Zero to Hero and fire off its powerful Jet Punch. Due to its frequent need to switch and reliance on a recoil move to wallbreak, Palafin requires effective entry hazard removers like Corviknight and Donphan; WishPass Scream Tail is also a great teammate to heal off chip damage. Even with its strong coverage moves, Palafin struggles mightily against opposing Desolate Land, so reliable switch-ins like Well-Baked Body Slither Wing are strongly recommended. Palafin struggles against Dondozo, making teammates that can punish it like Meowscarada and Spikes Garchomp good additions.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: A pure Water typing, titanic physical bulk, and Tablets of Ruin make Dondozo a nearly impenetrable physical wall that can blanket check common physical attackers including Cinderace, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao. Other options like Unaware can be used to ignore setup sweepers and wallbreakers that attempts to boost past Dondozo, while Magic Guard prevents it from being overwhelmed by entry hazards, Toxic, and Wave Crash recoil. Aside from turning it into a bulky setup sweeper, Curse also lets Dondozo contest with opposing setup from the likes of Talonflame and Kingambit, especially on non-Unaware variants. Earthquake is a necessary coverage move to hit Toxapex and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ceruledge. Rest + Leftovers provide much needed longevity, with Rest preventing Dondozo from being permanently crippled by Clodsire's Toxic, Iron Moth's Toxic Spikes, and Volcarona and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp. Special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Corviknight are necessary to deal with special attackers like Iron Moth, Sandy Shocks, and Chi-Yu respectively; the former three spread further passive damage onto foes between entry hazards, Toxic, Ruination, and Salt Cure, slowly whittling down foes for Dondozo to sweep easier. In return, Dondozo covers the likes of Quaquaval and Cinderace for them.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Tatsugiri is a decent Nasty Plot user that is able to threaten slower foes with its powerful STAB moves and it provides further utility by functioning as a spinner for teams that appreciate more hazard control. Magic Guard affords Tatsugiri some additional safety from entry hazards and chip damage from the likes of Salt Cure and Toxic. Instead of Hydro Pump, Surf can be used for more reliability. Tatsugiri is able to come in on and threaten spinblockers such as Skeledirge and Brambleghast, allowing it to use Nasty Plot or Rapid Spin on prediction. If left unchecked, Tatsugiri may be able to rack up enough boosts from Nasty Plot + Rapid Spin to serve as a frail sweeper. Due to its mediocre physical bulk, Tatsugiri appreciates physical walls such as Corviknight, which can also serve as a slow pivot to bring Tatsugiri safely into a favorable matchup. Tatsugiri also pairs well with physical attackers, such as Cinderace, that can threaten special walls such as Florges and Blissey, which Tatsugiri struggles against. Tatsugiri also appreciates entry hazards or other chip damage to secure KOs that it would typically miss, so Garganacl, with its ability to use Salt Cure and Stealth Rock, is a helpful teammate. Due to its low Speed, Tatsugiri appreciates faster teammates that can act as speed control, such as Chien-Pao or priority users such as Hatterene.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: A unique defensive typing, reliable recovery, and remarkable special bulk enhanced by Vessel of Ruin allow Clodsire to check prominent special attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon. Toxic can cripple Heavy-Duty Boots users like Volcarona and Kilowattrel. Corrosion + Toxic notably hits Corviknight and Toxapex, which are common switch ins and wears them down. Toxic Spikes and Poison Jab are better on Prankster sets to punish Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu; in particular, Toxic Spikes lets Clodsire match up well against hyper offense teams filled with setup sweepers. Prankster + Haze allows Clodsire to shut down setup sweepers, like Volcarona and Polteageist, while they whittle down from poison damage. Pokemon like Garganacl and Scream Tail form a hazard-stacking core with Clodsire. Physical walls like the aforementioned Pokemon, Corviknight, and Dondozo handle physical threats such as Quaquaval and Earth Eater Kingambit that can exploit Clodsire's poor physical bulk.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit excels as a mid-game wallbreaker that can boost on passive foes and tear through the opponent's team with its Adaptability-boosted STAB attacks. Kowtow Cleave and Iron Head are Kingambit's main attacks, heavily damaging defensive pivots like Corviknight, Hisuian Goodra, Scream Tail, and Garganacl. Sucker Punch lets it predict and punish faster attackers like Quaquaval, Volcarona, and Slither Wing that try and come in to revenge kill. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed uninvested Corviknight and Skeledirge. Black Glasses lets Kingambit OHKO Iron Moth with Sucker Punch. Immunity abilities like Well-Baked Body and Earth Eater are options to pick up additional setup chances. Fast endgame sweepers like Chien-Pao, Meowscarada, and Hisuian Electrode benefit from Kingambit's early-game presence, capitalizing on chipped foes and scoring easy KOs. Defensive pivots like Intimidate Corviknight, RegenVest Meloetta, and Fluffy Landorus-T can thwart revenge killers targeting Kingambit and use U-turn to bring it in safely again. Finally, Primordial Sea Zapdos can help Kingambit by forcing Corviknight and Quaquaval, two of its most consistent checks, letting it chip them on their switch-in repeatedly.

sets.name: Offensive Bulk Up
sets.description: Other viable abilities include: Scrappy, Sword of Ruin, Well-Baked Body, Water Absorb, Sap Sipper.

sets.name: Unaware
sets.description: Unaware Scream Tail is a premier defensive threat in the metagame, capable of walling foes such as Azelf, Roaring Moon, and Quaquaval, stonewalling most setup attempts, and being a powerful wincon. Wish + Protect is vital to ensure Scream Tail's health throughout the match, and it is also useful for healing teammates like Kingambit and Slither Wing, which often lack recovery of their own and are prone to being chipped down throughout a match. Calm Mind is suggested to ensure Scream Tail can become a late-game wincon, but Thunder Wave can be run instead as further team support for Hex users like Skeledirge and Hisuian Typhlosion. Encore and Stealth Rock can also be used for further protection against setup sweepers and role compression, respectively. Unaware ensures it can check boosted foes like Chien-Pao and opposing Calm Mind users like Triage Enamorus-T. 20 Speed EVs ensure it will always outspeed Hoopa, Volcanion, and Adamant Slither Wing. Scream Tail is taken advantage of by common Steel-, Fire-, and Poison-types like Hisuian Goodra, Hisuan Arcanine, and Iron Moth, so switch-ins to them like Heatran, Garchomp, and Alolan Muk are recommended; they also benefit from Scream Tail's Wish. Teammates that are weak to Fighting- and Psychic-type attacks like Iron Treads and Galarian Zapdos greatly appreciate Scream Tail's ability to switch into them.

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Scream Tail uses its excellent bulk and Speed to set up Calm Minds, while the power of Pixilate Boomburst makes up for its lackluster Special Attack stat. Wish + Protect provides Scream Tail with longevity and excellent defensive utility on a team, allowing it to help check threats like Galarian Zapdos, Garchomp, and Choice Band Slither Wing,. It can also opt to beat more of its checks with coverage; Psyshock 2HKOes Iron Moth at +1, and Focus Blast OHKOes Kingambit and 2HKOes non-RegenVest Iron Treads at +1. Scream Tail can also opt for Stealth Rock or Thunder Wave to cripple checks such as Corviknight and Heatran. Scream Tail struggles to break through common Fire-types like Heatran, Hisuian Arcanine, and Iron Moth without coverage, so it appreciates teammates like RegenVest Goodra, Primordial Sea Zapdos, and Well-Baked Body Iron Treads handling these threats. The latter two can also pivot Scream Tail into their switch-ins like Garchomp and Corviknight. Scream Tail also struggles against Unaware Pokemon like Cresselia and opposing Scream Tail; as such, teammates like Dragon Tail Hisuian Goodra, Toxapex, and Alolan Muk are appreciated to force them out.

sets.name: Regenerator
sets.description: Scream Tail is a solid defensive pivot for strong physical attackers such as Slither Wing and Chien-Pao that is able to have great longevity thanks to Regenerator. Scream Tail also makes for a good Wish passer for bulky teammates that lack reliable recovery such as Garchomp, Volcanion, and Zamazenta-C as it can pass Wish to them while also recovering on its own with Regenerator. Encore is used to stop set up threats like Quaquaval and Kingambit, while also being able to waste PP on Corviknight's and Zapdos's Roosts. Thunder Wave can be used to cripple fast threats like Chien-Pao and Talonflame, making it easier for them to be revenge killed, while Stealth Rock can provide entry hazard support for a team. Scream Tail can opt to run Rocky Helmet to more punish Sword of Ruin Galarian Zapdos, Meloetta, and Corviknight, Heavy-Duty Boots provides better longevity against hazards, while Choice Scarf can be used in conjunction with Trick to cripple defensive walls like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra while also being able to stop potential set up attempts. Iron Treads makes for a good partner with Scream Tail as it can remove hazards while Scream Tail can switch-in on incoming Fighting-type moves and also Wish pass to Iron Treads, allowing it to last much longer. Slower offensive Pokemon such as Hoopa and Volcanion also appreciate Scream Tail, as its able to spread paralysis on faster offensive Pokemon, making it easier for them to sweep. Scream Tail is vulnerable to strong special attackers like Thundurus-T, Iron Moth, and Magic Guard Heatran and since it also takes up the Regenerator ability slot, it is highly recommended to run a special wall with reliable recovery like Blissey or specially defensive Iron Moth that can withstand strong special attackers.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing leverages its large base Attack and STAB Close Combat, U-turn, and First Impression to serve as an extremely potent wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Flare Blitz is preferred on Tinted Lens sets, allowing it to 2HKO Intimidate and Fluffy Corviknight, while Earthquake is an option to hit checks like non-Earth Eater Skeledirge and Toxapex when running Sword of Ruin. Tinted Lens better allows Slither Wing to revenge kill foes, do more damage to switch-ins with U-turn, and more easily break potential checks like Zapdos and Toxapex while Sword of Ruin grants more overall power for neutral targets such as Fluffy Quaquaval. Slither Wing pairs well with special wallbreakers like Magic Guard Hisuian Electrode and Hydreigon, which can threaten Slither Wing's checks and pivot it in on special walls for it to break. Faster offensive cleaners like Chien-Pao and Meowscarada also pair well with Slither Wing for their ability to handle fast threats and overload physical walls. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and Iron Treads also partner well with Slither Wing, as they're able to safely pivot Slither Wing it in to break wallbreak, and they also absorb revenge killing attempts; furthermore, they are particularly useful for their ability to remove entry hazards, which wear down Slither Wing quickly throughout a game as it pivots frequently.

sets.name: Magic Guard
sets.description: Magic Guard Slither Wing serves as a revenge killer that aims to wear down and outlast its checks. Slither Wing possesses a unique combination of a strong STAB First Impression, U-turn, and Close Combat that is further boosted by a recoilless Life Orb with Magic Guard, which also allows it to switch in freely without racking up chip damage from entry hazards. Flare Blitz allows Slither Wing to hit checks like Intimidate Corviknight harder, while Earthquake hits walls like Toxapex and Skeledirge effectively, Will-O-Wisp can cripple checks like Fluffy Quaquaval and help to wear down defensive checks with added chip damage, and Morning Sun allows Slither Wing to remain healthy throughout a game. Specially offensive threats like Hisuian Electrode and Primordial Sea Inteleon pair well with Slither Wing for its ability to pivot and bring them in on physical walls to force them out and wear them down as well as for opportunities to wallbreak; together, they form a deadly VoltTurn core. Fast physical threats like Meowscarada and Chien-Pao also work well in combination Slither Wing to continuously wear down and overwhelm common physical walls like Corviknight, Quaquaval, and Scream Tail. Reliable hazard setters like Garchomp and Heatran are also appreciated to help wear down checks like Corviknight over the game and take advantage of the plethora of switches Slither Wing forces. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and RegenVest Meloetta are recommended to help pivot Slither Wing in to wallbreak and also absorb revenge killing attempts from the likes of Galarian Zapdos and Iron Moth.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Iron Moth and Hydreigon, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and the former can also fire off Terrain-boosted Discharge. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Ground Immunity
sets.description: Iron Treads is an excellent spinner that is able to switch into common entry hazard setters such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with its own Levitate while also being able to use Knock Off on common switch-ins such as Corviknight. Iron Treads can opt to be a hazard setter itself with Stealth Rock, keep up momentum with Volt Switch on targets like Corviknight, or use Heavy Slam as a strong STAB option for Scream Tail and Chien-Pao. Levitate allows Iron Treads to be immune to Spikes while also being able to spin them away, whereas Earth Eater can be used as an alternative for better longevity against hazard setters like Garchomp and Smack Down Landorus-T. Offensive Pokemon that are weak to hazards such as Chien-Pao and Thundurus-T appreciate Iron Treads's ability to keep hazards off the field, as well as being able to pivot them in safely with Volt Switch. Strong physical attackers like Galarian Zapdos and Kingambit also are good teammates for Iron Treads, as they can more easily break through Corviknight with Knock Off support from Iron Treads. Iron Treads can be overwhelmed by coverage options from hazard setters such as Liquidation Garchomp, so running Wish Scream Tail, which can increase Iron Treads's longevity, or a secondary hazard remover like Corviknight and Quaquaval, which can also stave off hits, is recommended. Iron Treads is also vulnerable to strong Fighting-type attackers such as Galarian Zapdos and Slither Wing, so it is advised to pair it with a Fighting-resistant teammate such as Scream Tail or Fluffy Zapdos.

sets.name: Fire Immunity
sets.description: Well-Baked Body Iron Treads is a spinner with a great defensive typing in addition to a Fire immunity and ability to compress several roles such as item and entry hazard removal into one Pokemon. It is notably able to threaten the tier's premier spinblocker in Skeledirge, allowing it to remove hazards freely. If there is already a Stealth Rock user on the team, Iron Treads can instead use Heavy Slam to check Calm Mind Scream Tail and Enamorus-T, Rock Slide to OHKO Talonflame and Volcarona, or Volt Switch to bring in teammates safely. 236 Speed EVs are used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO on Jolly Hisuian Arcanine. Pixilate Scream Tail and Primordial Sea users like Inteleon, Greninja, and Quaquaval all appreciate Iron Treads switching into their checks in Desolate Land Fire-types like Iron Moth and Ceruledge. Physical wallbreakers like Chien-Pao and Hisuian Arcanine appreciate Iron Treads removing items from shared switch-ins like Corviknight and Quaquaval. Fighting- and Ground- types like Galarian Zapdos, Slither Wing, and Garchomp threaten Iron Treads, so defensive partners like Scream Tail, Quaquaval, and Corviknight are recommended. Iron Treads's Rapid Spin also supports the hazard stacking effort from partners like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Certain Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge can still threaten Iron Treads with their coverage moves, so it appreciates a secondary check to them like Primordial Sea Zapdos.

sets.name: Sheer Force
sets.description: With high-Base Power moves and decent Special Attack and Speed, Iron Jugulis is a solid wallbreaker that can outspeed and threaten common specially defensive foes, like Garchomp and Garganacl. Iron Jugulis offers a notable niche, as Hurricane + Dark Pulse + Focus Blast can hit every viable Pokemon for neutral damage. Taunt disrupts attempts to heal, set up, or set entry hazards, allowing Iron Jugulis to better handle Pokemon such as Blissey and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis struggles against special walls like Florges and Scream Tail, so physically offensive teammates like Cinderace and Ceruledge are necessary to break through them. Due to its frailty, it enjoys teammates like Slither Wing and Corviknight that can pivot it in, the latter of which can also remove hazards with Defog. Iron Jugulis also appreciates entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu, which can enable it to secure KOs that it would typically miss, such as Garganacl.

sets.name: All Out Attacker
sets.description: Iron Moth is a potent and aggressive special attacker with access to relevant STAB attacks and convenient coverage options. Flamethrower and Sludge Wave help Iron Moth dispatch of Almost Any Ability's staple Steel- and Fairy-types like Corviknight and Scream Tail as well as outputting massive damage to anything that doesn't resist its attacks. Fire Blast can be used for more damage output, outdamaging RegenVest Meloetta and Hisuian Goodra's Regenerator healing. Energy Ball can be used instead of Sludge Wave to help Iron Moth's matchup with Well-Baked Body Iron Treads and Regenerator Ting-Lu. Dazzling Gleam improves Iron Moth's offensive chances against Dragon-types like Garchomp and Roaring Moon. Discharge is a coverage alternative that hits Well-Baked Body Corviknight as well as becoming a monstrously strong offensive option when combined with Iron Moth's alternate ability, Hadron Engine. Additionally, Hadron Engine helps Iron Moth score a 2HKO on specially defensive Garchomp with Dazzling Gleam. Balance and offense teams that appreciate explosive offensive power look forward to having Iron Moth as a teammate, as it can easily wipe some defensive pivots like Corviknight and Scream Tail off of the opponent's team. Additionally, Iron Moth struggles heavily against special walls like Garchomp, Garganacl, and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, so heavy hitters like Kingambit and Slither Wing can be used to make progress against these, making it easier for Iron Moth to sweep late-game. Finally, tools found on hyper offense teams like dual screens, Sticky Web, and entry hazard stacking help Iron Moth more effectively avoid revenge killers and more easily eliminate any of its switch-ins.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Chien-Pao is a fast and hard-hitting attacker able to burst through many weakened teams with little struggle, with its strong Ice- and Dark-type STAB moves and a Choice Band to increase its already good Attack to threaten many popular defensive Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Mandibuzz, and Zapdos. Chien-Pao uses Sacred Sword in order to guarantee an OHKO on Pokemon like Kingambit, Heatran, and Hisuian Goodra, as well as heavily chipping Zamazenta-C. It can also use Lash Out over Crunch, which can 2HKO Intimidate Corviknight after Stealth Rock damage, though getting extra chip on Corviknight can help to guarantee the 2HKO. With Chien-Pao having one of the highest Speed tiers, it's able to pick up OHKOs on many frailer offensive Pokemon like Ogerpon-C and Gengar, it also works excellently as a revenge killer because of Ice Shard and it's its aforementioned high Speed able to take down weakened Pokemon or force out Pokemon like Ceruledge, Zapdos, and Azelf. Offensive Pivots such as Barraskewda and Hisuian Electrode appreciate Chien-Pao's presence, as they like being able to pivot into Chien-Pao to deal with Hisuian Goodra or Corviknight. Chien-Pao is weak to entry hazards, limiting how many times it can come in, so teammates like Corviknight, Mandibuzz, and Great Tusk can all help with it whilst also taking hits that Chien-Pao can't take and pivoting to get it in safely. Even with help from pivoting, Chien-Pao does have a hard time breaking through common foes such as defensive Corviknight, Unaware Scream Tail, and Quaquaval, which can all switch in on it fairly easily, but the help of teammates like Mixed Garchomp, Magic Guard Heatran, and Hisuian Electrode can help deal with its checks.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Earth Eater Kingambit, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Talonflame and Quaquaval. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Lucario can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammate that also provides Defog.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Hydreigon and Iron Moth. Throat Chop provides STAB damage and lets it beat Boomburst users, Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce Ting-Lu's weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Cinderace and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Sand Stream Garganacl and non-Unaware Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Meowscarada and Kingambit make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Roaring Moon is a fierce wallbreaker that dents large holes in balance teams and has specific coverage to beat its would-be checks. Strong Jaw-boosted Fire Fang threatens Zamazenta-C and Fluffy Corviknight attempting to tank Crunch while Thunder Fang OHKOes Galarian Zapdos and 2HKOes defensive Quaquaval. U-turn allows it to maintain momentum in the face of hard counters like Hippowdon and a healthy Corviknight while also being a midground option for predicted switch-ins. An Adamant nature gives Roaring Moon a chance of OHKOing Hisuian Goodra and is guaranteed to 2HKO Corviknight and Quaquaval, while a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed and threaten Azelf and Iron Moth. Roaring Moon pairs well with other physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Chien-Pao and Meowscarada that can clean up teams after checks like Zamazenta-C and Quaquaval have been removed. Pivots like Zapdos, Regieleki, and Hisuian Electrode form a VoltTurn core with Roaring Moon that wears down each other's checks. Roaring Moon's unimpressive physical bulk and weakness-laden typing mean that it is a prime target of revenge killers like Slither Wing and Triage Enamorus-T; walls like Corviknight and Hisuian Goodra pair well with Roaring Moon, as they absorb revenge killing attempts while providing defensive utility that Roaring Moon lacks.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description: Walking Wake's excellent Special Attack, good Speed, and nearly unresisted STAB combination allow it to stand out as either a threatening wallbreaker or powerful speed control depending on its choice of item. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Empoleon and RegenVest Manaphy, Scald provides a more reliable STAB option on non-Primordial Sea sets while also threatening a burn on potential switch-ins, while Dragon Pulse provides a more reliable Dragon-type STAB move. Flip Turn is used in order to gain momentum for Walking Wake's teammates while also pivoting out of unfavorable matchups such as against Empoleon and Blissey. Primordial Sea allows Walking Wake to run Weather Ball instead of Hydro Pump, trading power for accuracy while also giving Walking Wake an easier time switching into Fire-types thanks to the Fire-type immunity. Dragon's Maw significantly boosts the power of Walking Wake's Dragon-type attacks, notably allowing it to OHKO RegenVest Manaphy after a Knock Off and one layer of entry hazards, at the cost of not increasing the power of its Water-type attacks and providing no additional defensive benefit. A Choice Specs can be used in order to increase Walking Wake's effectiveness as a wallbreaker, notably allowing non-Primordial Sea sets to 2HKO RegenVest Manaphy and Hisuian Goodra with Draco Meteor after a Knock Off, while a Choice Scarf can be used to outspeed and threaten an OHKO against would-be offensive checks, such as Weavile, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon. Walking Wake appreciates offensive teammates such as Galarian Zapdos, Meowscarada, and Ogerpon-C, which can pressure switch-ins like Empoleon, RegenVest Manaphy, and Desolate Land Heatran. Fast teammates such as Barraskewda and Choice Scarf Azelf also pair well with Walking Wake, as they appreciate the holes it breaks in the opponent's team while forming a VoltTurn core with the momentum they generate, potentially allowing them to sweep late-game. These teammates can also force out Walking Wake's offensive checks, such as Weavile, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon, which can outspeed it and threaten it with an OHKO.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: With its high Attack stat and variety of Sharpness-boosted moves, Iron Leaves is a decent wallbreaker that can OHKO common metagame threats like Garganacl and Quaquaval. Sacred Sword allows Iron Leaves to hit Grass- and Psychic-resistant foes like Kingambit and Hydreigon, while Wild Charge threatens Flying-types like Talonflame and Corviknight. Iron Leaves struggles with being prediction-reliant and having low physical bulk, especially with its 4x weakness to the extremely prevalent U-turn, which makes wrong predictions very punishing. Therefore, having defensive teammates like Ting-Lu and Corviknight that can repeatedly pivot it in safely are necessary. Due to its lack of recovery and need for repeated switching, Iron Leaves appreciates entry hazard removers like Iron Treads to keep it from getting worn down. Hadron Engine users like Sandy Shocks are also great teammates that power up both Psyblade and Wild Charge with Electric Terrain.
